NOTES ON AIRPORT
Tuesday, Sept. 14, 1926.
Called on Mr. Shaw,
South San Francisco Land and Improve-
ment Company, Merchants Exchange Building.
Suggested that the limit to be paid by the City for the
100 acres involved in site No. 2 would be $260,000.00, provided that
the land be brought to an elevation of plus 10 feet by the present
owner; that in addition, the Land Company would have to include
a right of way for a spur track from the Belt Railroad into the
proposed aeroplane
site.
Mr.
Shaw stated that
if we submitted the offer it would
be forwarded
to his company, but that he would not recommend its
acceptance.
Mr. Shaw's
mentioned
price on the above site as per the conditions
above is $340,000.00 for an area
01 approximately 100
acres.

Mr. Howard Sr. and Mr. Howard Jr.,
They agreed to sell to the City all land that we wish
east of
both
the present transmission line and including the land on
sides of the Bay Shore Boulevard, with the exception of two
easements for road purposes at
the northerly and southerly
boundaries, these
easements to be used for road purposes only.
Would deliver the
same subject to confirmation on the part of
Mrs.
Taylor for $2,000.00 per acre.
I stated to them that the price should be between $750.00
and $1,000.00

Mr. Howard Sr.

NOTES ON AIRPORT
Friday, Sept. 17, 1926.
At the request of the Chamber of Commerce and suggested
by the Supervisors attending the luncheon to Assistant Secretary
of the Navy Warner,
I met Mr. Warner and the officers of the
Twelfth Naval Division at Harrison and Spear Streets
at 2:30 o'clock.
We left about 3:00 o'clock and visited the South San Francisco site
and Millbrae site.
Did not visit the San Mateo
site, as it was not
suitable for hydroplanes.
Returned to San Francisco
at 4:45 o'clock.
The Assistant Secretary expressed the opinion that the
site at
planes,
South San Francisco was not admirably adapted for hydro-
as the hydroplane would probably have to taxi
at some three
before it
could start to rise.
Depth of water is needed for
hydroplanes,
according to the Assistant
Secretary,
in order to enable
boats
deliver supplies direct to the hydroplanes.
We also visited the Millbrae site and the Assistant
Secretary
said that
it appeared to him
that this was
a much better
Not being familiar with the direction of the winds at all
times he could not state whether it was ideal or not.
He also asked
concerning drainage
on both sites and whether during
the winter
season the land would be waterlogged.
He also made
the statement
that if it were a
question of securing a field not suitable for
hydroplanes but absolutely clear of
that he would select that
field rather than
take a field suitable
for hydroplanes that had
fog at times.
party;
Mr.
Guersey of the Chamber of Commerce accompanied the
also Rear-Admiral Thomas Washington,
